Cell phone usage is out of hand. Some people talk on the phone during their entire work out. Distracting and annoying. People walking and reading texts thru crowded workout areas-unsafe. Gym has/had policy against phone calls on workout floor-was in contract but staff don't seem to know anything about this when asked. I'm guessing other gyms are seeing an acceleration in cell phone usage. Ugh...

This was my very first cycling experience, and man was it breathtaking, literally! TMI but I've never sweat so much in my entire life. The instructor was an amazing motivator and made the 45 minutes fly by. The music choice was great and the mood lighting was super cool. I've already signed up for a package! So impressed with the up-to-date bikes and the friendly atmosphere you receive immediately upon arrival. If you're in the market for a spectacular cycling class, look no further. Pedal Pedal Cycling Studio is the place to try!

I love coming here and how friendly everyone working is every single time I come in. It's never too crowded even during peak week day gym hours. Very lucky a gym this nice with a staff this friendly is near my house. Overall, it's very clean and all the machines are always in working condition. Sometimes I've found that the free weights are a little dirty and that gets on my clothes so that's my one comment that I'm sure isn't unique to this gym. 

It's a pretty even split of men and women and a decent amount of older individuals working out. Sometimes when I go in the evening it's a lot of men pumping iron but there's some good girl power represented on plenty of days. :)

I got the living social deal here, 1 month unlimited for $39. It was a great purchase. I love rowzone and will definitely be coming after my month is up. They vary up arms, legs, and core workouts with a good bit of cardio on different days so it never seems the same, and they keep fun music on overhead.
Gym is small & very overcrowded. Aside from that, they want you to wash your hands with shampoo. No I would not recommend this gym.

Inspired by the recent Yelp Wellness Week, I decided to try a class here. It is free to try your first class. I am not really a group fitness or class person but I have heard good things about Orangetheory and this location is near my house so I figured, why not?

When you take a free class, you do have to arrive a half hour early to fill out paperwork, get fixed up with a heart monitor (like a fit bit) and take a short tour. The front desk person (Jess) was super nice, and went over my fitness goals with me, then introduced me to the trainer/instructor before the class. Ashley was the trainer I met with. She is really high energy and positive. She explained the process to me, where I would be for each part of the class and so on.

Classes here are an hour long and divided into three parts, treadmill, rowing machine and weights/floor exercises. You rotate through each. The heart rate thing keeps track of where your heart rate is, if it is in the "orange zone" and so on. Apparently you want to be in the orange zone because that is where you are really pushing yourself. I was not there, but I still burned almost 400 calories during my session and I felt like I was challenging myself. During the workout you are not expected to try and keep up with everyone else, if you can only do one rep of the three exercises then that is ok. I kept up pretty good, and Ashley also had some alternative exercises for me because I could not do the others with my knee. They play upbeat fun music the whole time as well.

If I was going to join a gym, this is the top runner thus far. One of the main reasons I am not joining at this time though is the cost. You have to purchase a monitor (99 for the wrist one or 69 for a chest one) and it is 99 a month if you plan to do two classes a week. I am still going to keep it in mind though.

Nerds of the internet, you're probably familiar with "Delete Facebook, lawyer up, hit the gym." Now, I banned Facebook from my work, I luckily don't need a lawyer, but I did need to hit the gym to get out of a funk. I've been going to Christian Street for a couple months now, and am a fan. 

Sure, I'm not there a lot. But it's the first gym I've ever been to where my initial trainer appointment wasn't an upsell of personal training. The people here just want you to be happy and healthy and have fun (especially if you're going to a class).

I haven't been to many classes, but the few I've been to have been great. BodyPump is offered most days of the week for those who sometimes get lazy with their lifting schedule (*cough* me *cough*).

Most of my time there is spent in the weight room, and it's up to par. There's usualy the same trainer there in the morning (Kathy) and she's great about answering questions and generally being awesome. It gets crowded in the afternoon, but nowhere near what I consider "gym crowded" i.e. there's no required flow of traffic you have to follow, there are still lap lanes available to share, cardio machines available even if it's not your preferred one ...

So generally Christian Street is awesome. Plus, what can I say, I get a kick out of supporting community organizations like the Y. I walked back from the gym one Saturday to see a herd of 20+ members planting trees. Awesome.
Good gym. Never too crowded. Not enough spray bottles and towels to clean equipment. Not enough fans either - gym gets very hot.

Not the best AF. Not the worst. Tucked away in an old shopping plaza with shared parking between a Mexican restaurant and an IHOP, this AF has the standard machines most often used by the average gym-goer with just enough space to get in your workout without much bother. On entry (key fob required), there's a vending machine to the right and 5 treadmills, two stationary bikes, one stair master, and 2 or 3 elliptical to the left. The stair master is awkwardly placed right next to a large window which overlooks the outdoor seating area of the Mexican restaurant, and there are no curtains, so take note of that. 

AF reminds me of a surprisingly well stocked hotel gym. It has most of what you need. And again, I may even be more positively biased because I have multiple gym memberships through my health insurance, so I can't attest to whether the membership prices are appropriate. My main complaint really is the location. Who really wants to fight through a crowd of people waiting at either ihop or a Mexican restaurant... to work out?

It seems to be a clean gym. There are three disinfectant bottles and rags to wipe down machines. It's usually staffed with one or two people during the weekdays.  I've never seen more than 10 people at a time, which is great. 

Standard machines. Small turf area, but at least it's there. Some machines are a little cramped together, as others have noted.

First time rock climber and I became a quick pro. Much like Tom Cruise in the opening to the 2nd Mission Impossible movie's opening. Although he didn't have to fend off children.

The location was a pain to find. It is not well marked. Look for the tallest building.

I found the staff to be incredibly friendly and knowledgeable. A good combination for a beginner. They were also good about feeding into my ego by complimenting me on my fast skills.

There are many levels in the facility to keep you interested. I will definitely check it out again.

I absolutely love this gym! Not only are the trainers friendly they are also highly skilled when it comes to boxing you feel like you are getting great trainer advice. Title boxing is a place to go for an amazing fun workout you are sure to burn at least 500 calories if you put your all into it & that's a minimum. I have class pass which only allows 3 times per month but I'm thinking about getting a membership because I want to go more than 3 times per month!
Classes were well run with a very welcoming community. Great place to drop in if you're in the area.

My son (age 11) has been doing parkour for two year and training at a different facility in NJ which we both love.  Decided to take him to open gym at HFS because he enjoys trying out different equipment.  The experience was excellent.  It was a little hard to find the entrance as there is just a small sign on the door.  Parking was easy on the street on a sunday afternoon.  Facility was very different than my son's regular gym but he really liked it.  Some climbing apparatuses allowed him to practice his flips and landings from a much higher distance.  Staff was very attentive and happy to move mats to make different courses.  As is typical with the parkour community, everyone was super friendly and he found a group to practice with in a matter of minutes.  All in all, it was a great experience for his ability level.  

In addition, I wanted to note that even though it was open gym, a staff member was introducing newbies to basic moves, etc...  He vetted my son out quickly and allowed him to go on his way but it's great that they take the time to make sure everyone knows how to use the gym safely.
Lovely staff.  A super chill club with everything you need.  Clean with all the gym activities one needs.

I would say by my fifth class at Sculpt I really felt like I was getting the hang of it. I can't do everything 100% still (it's TOUGH, and somehow I'm dripping sweat while everyone else looks pretty and effortless.. story of my life!!!), but I know what the moves are when the teacher mentions them.

The way the teaching works here, the instructor will mention the move and demo it in front of you while you're finishing the previous move, then again as you move into it. If there is a free machine they jump on and do it, usually. I find that some instructors are better than others at clearly demo-ing the move. Stephanie the owner is my favorite for this not only because she is super positive and friendly, but she consistently demo's the moves and gives gentle pointers on form and noticing when your knee goes over your ankle in lunges, etc.

First of all, The Monon Center is more than a gym..and that is why we are fans. 

Here you'll find the standard indoor fitness center fare: weights, cardio machines, group classes, running track, basketball courts, etc. But, the Monon is nestled in a park, which makes it rather unique among fitness facilities. The complex also includes meeting rooms, an indoor and outdoor pool and outdoor water park, skate park, gardens, and walking/jogging trail that winds through the park and around a fishing pond and wetlands. Monon is also close, as evidenced by its name, to the Monon Trail or Greenway, whichever you choose to call it.

The fees at Monon are reasonable and the facilities clean and functional. Apparently, much thought was given to the esthetic of the building in terms of keeping it as "green" as possible. Think bamboo flooring, native landscaping and such. 

A family-friendly fitness center/park if ever there was one!
Also holds various special events and recreation classes throughout the year.
Good price, plenty of equipment.  Knowledgeable Personal Trainers.  Gets a little busy between 6 and 8 pm.

First, the positive. With few exceptions the instructors (spin, TRX, etc.) are fantastic, and most classes are included in membership fee. Personal trainers are extra, but worth it if you have the money and don't mind pain. And the facility has almost everything you'd need: pool, tennis courts, squash courts, indoor track, basketball courts, weights, machines, hot tub, sauna, steam room, cold plunge, showers, lockers, childcare, etc. Finally, at least for me, it's really close. 

There are increasing number of negatives, however. As almost all other reviews point out, the place is falling apart. The roof above the indoor track leaks so whenever it rains you have to dodge all the buckets that are deployed (and it's freezing in there). Cardio and weight machines are often broken and sometimes have "being fixed!" signs attached for months. There are hundreds of more cosmetic issues, too, like ripped carpets, broken mirrors, and strange stains on the walls. These cosmetic issues shouldn't change the quality of your workout but there's something about seeing everything held together by old duct tape that drains my energy level a tad.     

People having conversations on cell phones is also an issue, though perhaps that's true at all clubs these days. It just seems that the Healthplex has a high percentage of alpha males who conduct business deals (real estate, stocks) over the phone and who think the rest of the gym would benefit from the hearing the details. They are loud and laugh off staff who try to quiet them. Management seems loathe to intervene out of fear of losing members. I take headphones even though I don't find them comfortable to wear.

It might not be a problem for everyone, but another negative for me is that Fox News is almost always blasting away in the men's locker room ... just too much yelling for me. Given the conversations I overhear in various parts of the gym, I think majority of members are fans of Fox News so maybe gym is just trying to please the majority (I get that). That explanation would fit with the apparent age demographics (older, male) of the Healthplex, which initially (I think) served as physical therapy offshoot for the attached Springfield Hospital. 

Locker room is fine, though some of the showers seem to lack hot water. One perk for the daring is complimentary deodorant in unlabeled spray bottles. Not sure why they even provide it. Perhaps it's a hint. And there's lots of couch space around the television, plus a faux leather recliner. FYI (and TMI), it's not an infrequent site to see a completely naked person on the couch, though presumably he's recently showered. One can hope, at least. I've also seen men asleep on the recliner. Not that there's anything wrong with that. Also, naked guys shaving, resting against sink. In other gyms guys seem to cover themselves in towels. When in Rome, I guess. 

Broadly, I get the sense (from looking at faces and hearing snippets of conversations) that employees are deeply unhappy with management and that the facility is always on brink of insolvency. Seems less crowded than in previous years so I'm guessing it's bleeding members to local gyms that are 1/4 the price and have a more upbeat vibe. There's also probably a few deaths every year -- I see some people for years ... and then they just stop coming. I've never seen anyone just keel over, though.

I think the manager is keenly aware of building issues, equipment age, and demography imbalance. He's probably making changes and improvements that members can't see, but one action that's apparent and troubling to me is the use of Twitter and Facebook ads that feature a completely different gym, one that is gleaming and has modern, unbroken equipment. The ads also tend to feature young female models from Shutterstock's "Sporty Girl" collection, not actual members of the gym. I mention this because the women in the ads are often shown with midriff-revealing athletic tops ... which are banned at the actual Healthplex. I think the photographs are from a gym in Novi Sad, Serbia, near the Danube. I hope to go there someday.

I'm wondering whether the California holding company that owns the Healthplex is trying to find a buyer and just doesn't want to put any money into a property that is already in debt.

After spending this past year with crunch fitness here Brandon I decided to go back to Planet Fitness in Seffner. I joined crunch fitness because of its proximity to my home (1 mile) in Brandon . I'm way more comfortable at Planet Fitness and PF has a lot more treadmills, ellipticals, cycling machines, etc. The only thing I miss about crunch is the Bluetooth connectivity that the treadmills and stair masters have with Apple watches, this eliminates the need to keep your hands on the sensors. Also, I think adding at least 2 more stair machines would be awesome especially since the current COVID-19 guidelines have taken 2 of the 4 stair machines offline. Also, please add a sanitization station on the east wall (locker room side) behind the the line of treadmills. Keep up the great work with the current cleaning regiment. Lastly, is there any future plans of a Planet Fitness in Brandon? The the now closed Youfit by the mall is just sitting empty, that would be an ideal location

Updating this review because I have been at this gym for about six months now and I am still hooked!

For starters, just six weeks into working out here I had an in-body assessment done to see the progress I made from when I first signed up. When I looked at my results I was a bit shocked--I was 3 lbs heavier than when I first started. But then I looked at the breakdown and realized I had gained 4 lbs of muscle & lost 2.5% body fat! That, my friends, is results if you ask me! 

All of the workouts are very thoughtfully structured and set you up to get stronger while minimizing the risk of injury. I feel like not only am I stronger, healthier, and more energized now than I was when I first started here, I also have more flexibility and experience less soreness/stiffness. (I used to get gnarly shin stiffness when running, and that problem has subsided so much that it is practically nonexistent.)

Aside from my stoked-ness (def just made that word up) about my in-body test results and my increase of strength, I am hooked on the culture of this gym. It doesn't matter whose class I go to, I always have a great work out and genuinely have so much fun.  The instructors are awesome, but there is also such a positive, encouraging and welcoming vibe that all the members of this gym have. 

Final thoughts: Clearly, I highly recommend this gym. And more specifically, I highly recommend signing up for their unlimited classes. It is a bit spendy and more than what you would pay for a standard gym pass, but (if you actually go consistently) it is absolutely worth it as it is a wonderful investment in your health and quite frankly, your confidence. These classes give you workouts that are made with a lot of strategy behind them, trainers that will help you get strong and fit in a safe way, and provide a fun/non-intimidating fitness community to be apart of.

For real, my final thoughts: There is no start up fee, no cancellation fee, no once yearly "gym upkeep" fee (rolling my eyes at another gym whose name I shall not mention here). Jack City keeps it simple: once a month a withdraw comes out of your bank account. You can cancel anytime--no questions asked. **Praise hands** for a gym that cuts all that nonsense out, is straightforward, and just gives people what they come to a gym looking for in the first place--a dang good workout.

Great gym for the price. Never really crowded at all. Their equipment could use a little updating, but it gets the job done. The hand dryers in the bathroom are terrible. Not much of a complaint, haha but I am better off blowing on my hands or wiping on my shirt.

Scam! I joined the month to month plan and haven't been there in 2 yrs. ABC Financial says the contract automatically renewed. What a joke! Stay away from this place because they scam you into the month to month and keep billing you when you don't renew! Gym called me today and said I owe them $150. Said if I didn't pay they would turn it over to a collection agency! Stay away from them they will rip you off!

Great experience for a family outing.
Though I would have liked a simple return phone call as it took a while to get a hold of someone and left several voice mails.

The Carondelet YMCA, as a whole, is a nice facility. The gym is ok, but small. (Machines are sometimes down and out of commission for weeks). The basketball court is very nice, too. It's the most used area in the entire complex. What I'm partial to is the track that sits above the court on the second floor. Great overview of the lowel level and suits all cardio needs.

The indoor and outdoor pool settings are great! The kids really enjoy it. Such a great additive for those sweltering, Summer days.

But the customer service, though?!!!! Oh, no ma'am. The front desk is atrocious, so is the morale. First of all, why are there so many workers stationed at the front desk, yet none of them are barely paying attention. Furthermore, they all act like they have no clue what they're doing?  Listen, I don't understand. 

Another gripe I have is unruly children running around, swinging off gym equipment. I know part of the problem is the parents not stepping in. HOWEVER, there needs to be more workers, in all areas, enforcing rules about those matters. There's about 50-11 workers at the desk, folding towels...how many YMCA workers does it take to fold linen? Management should really check on that. It doesn't look good walking in and people in YMCA staff t-shirts all clustered together, doing nothing. 

The complex gives a safe and fun place for kids to fellowship and to stay out the streets. But in the customer service department, some changes need to happen.
My 4 year old LOVES gymnastics! We are continuously impressed by the patience the teachers have while instructing the little ones! They are wonderful!!!!!

We had a membership here. After a few months we decided it just wasn't working out for us and we cancelled our membership. We paid the cancellation fees and notified them in writing. For several months they kept trying to take money out of our checking account. After not hearing from them for well over a year, they are now trying to tell us that we never paid the cancellation fee and they are trying to take money out of our bank account. These people do not care about you or your fitness, they only care about the money. Avoid this headache and go get a membership at your local YMCA.

I never thought I would be able to get myself to the gym before 7am, but with Will I have found that motivation.  He is very supportive, whatever your ability, and encourages you to meet your goals without being pushy.  The group is small and non-judgmental, exactly what I love about it, everyone is there to workout and get fit.  I have been working out with Will now for six weeks and am so happy with the progress I am making.  Not only is my pre-baby body coming back, but I feel stronger and more in shape than ever before and I owe that all to Will.   I highly recommend anyone wanting to get in shape, to lose weight or to build up their strength to give Will a try, you will not regret it.  It is the best investment you can make.

This review is specifically for the water park. 

Our little one loved the water park! This isn't just a pool, they have a great variety of water areas, a kiddie splash pad enclosed for those under 48", a lazy river, a massive toddler/big kids playground, a pool, wave runner, water slide and more. Staff is amazing here. From the lifeguards, the janitorial service, ticket workers everyone is super friendly. I appreciate how well behave folks are here and attentive as it can be a bit overwhelming to see so many kids and so much water and activity but it's a great time. Come prepared as there is not much shade to lay under if it's a hot sunny day. Overall we really enjoyed it and look forward to coming back! 

Playground/Water activities: 5/5
Service: 5/5
Cleanliness: 5/5
Concessions: 4/5

The district manager Raymond Sweeney addressed all my concerns.  I was impressed with his professionalism but even more touched by his humanity.  Thank you Mr. Sweeney, Crunch Fitness is lucky to have you in their corner.

Joined in January 2015. Great gym. Group classes are excellent. Love the fact that there is a dry and wet steam room. The gym always seems clean to me, Housekeeping staff is always busy doing something. Kudos to the housekeeping staff thank you for dealing with our sweatiness!

It's a fantastic, large, no frills gym. If you simply want access to a large number of machines to exercise on your own, it's impossible to beat Planet Fitness at only $10/month. There's pretty good utilization of machines during the evening rush hour, like 4-7, but even at these peak times I can almost always find an open machine of the type I want. Plenty of parking and plenty of machines are this large location.

The bathroom, locker room, and showers are large, clean, and well maintained. I don't have any experience with their premium services - massage, tanning, or personal trainers.

I'm a black card member, so I've been to a fair number of planet fitness gyms. This was by far the worst. There is no signage for parking, which isn't helpful as the parking lot and entrance are on the opposite side of the building from the street. The locker rooms were missing hair dryer machines, and we're not clean. The hot water took about 10 mins to come on in the shower. (A lady in the shower next to me said she complained a few days ago as well about the hot water problem.) The gym equipment is fine--but the gym set-up is very crowded for the number of users for this location.

Wanted to stop by after work and discuss joining/amenities/offers/etc. no staff -States staffed until 6pm. Gave myself a little tour since no one was around and still no staff member. Left after 10-15 mins of waiting. Little disheartening that anyone can just open the guest door and walk the entire gym considering there's no employees on site given the specified times on their website. May give it another shot later this week...

I am not a member of this gym but I was here for a free Zumba party.  The parking lot was pretty busy for 6:30 on a weeknight and inside the gym it was busy with about half of the cardio machines occupied and many of the weight machines.  After we signed in, we were directed to the group fitness room.  We asked where the locker room was and was directed to it.  The lockers are really big and nice and just need to bring your own lock.  There's large mirrors too and a good number of bathroom stalls.

The group fitness room is big but it gets very hot and I wish there were fans or cooler temperature.  I'm not sure if they had the lights off but it was a bit dark.  The sound was good and the music pumping! Staff were fine but not the friendliest.

Seems like a decent gym but not sure how I would like it if I were a member and it was always busy and hot.

What a fun place! I've taken my daughter to a few of the kids' aerial classes and she is hooked! The instructors are so patient with newbies, and they couldn't be more welcoming.

I'm hoping they add additional classes, since the kids' class on Saturday is sort of crowded and the adult classes are on the weekends or in the evenings. And I want to take a class so badly! Y'all, it looks like a blast! 

I think this place is fantastic and I can't wait to climb into the silks and fly!

I wish I would've been doing this since I was a child. Working out has never been much of an issue for me, but after so long in the gym, everything becomes routine. Here, you'll get your work in and learn valuable skill sets at the same time. Nothing like a peace of mind coupled with physical fitness. 

If I ever have kids, they're doing this. If you have kids, they should do this. If you're reading this review, YOU should do this. It's definitely for everyone. I've partnerd with cats 70+ years old so there really are no excuses. 

Triumph has a very welcoming environment and attitude from all instructors. Not to mention a supportive class of students through and through. The things they teach you become like instinct and is sure to stick with you for a long time even after just a few sessions. Of course, the more you practice, the more of a machine you'll become. 

They have self defense, they have weapons training, they have cardio bags, they have yoga, kettlebells, monkey bar gym (conditioning); it's a full-body experience that will no doubt have you leaving with a sense of security and confidence moving forward. You will be worn out after each class but in the best kind of way. 

It's more than just pumping iron, it's mental, it's situational awareness, it's a lifestyle. Did I mention fun? Yeah, it's hella fun. Do it, thank yourself later. 

Great Job, guys (and gals)!

We love this place. My daughter enjoys coming here. The studio is huge with multiple areas. The schedule is flexible with various class opportunities. The facility is spotless and has such a friendly staff. You can tell each kid wants to go here. The owner is very active with his students, and the instructors are kind, fun, encouraging, and excellent at what they do. We like how they allow the kids to help teach the newer kids, so they both gain something. It's nice to see the teamwork. The kids learn about self-discipline, self-respect, respecting others, and confidence to believe in themselves. We can see my daughter growing and her self-esteem building. The skills she is learning in self-defense are priceless and lifelong. She knows friendship, respect, confidence, having an attitude that doesn't give up, and so much more. She is so proud of completing four belts.  The staff has been exceptional during this crazy pandemic. We couldn't have asked for a better program to work with our daughter during these trying times. We feel so blessed to have a place that has a flexible schedule, and that has fantastic instructors. We recommend everyone involving their children in this program and to this location.

Say what you want about the purple gym but it's pretty damn good.

Pros :
- clean. Employees there seem to do a very good job of keeping things clean and so do the people who work out there. For the most part everyone wipes down their machines, benches and equipment after they use it
- working condition. Everything works there. Equipment and machines are newer and well kept
- people. The people seem very chill for the most part. I've seen a few people there who definitely like to give the big boy bad boy looks as they're lifting their 2.5lb Dumbbells but that's expected at any gym. The purple must make some people angry


Cons: 
- some more equipment would be nice. I've been to other Planet Fitness gyms and many have the newest stair steppers, bench press and incline press that are free weights that are not all limited to the smith machines. 
- can get busy.....
- Dumbbells maxed at 60lbs which I get, don't need to get the 'lunks' rolling in but would like the preacher curl chair and other things available

I would say join. 20.00/month is unbeatable with all they have to offer

Just joined this gym and really liking it. I went with a special deal for a $10 basic plan that included a free shirt (score!) and membership at this gym minus the special perks like the hydro chair. All I need are the machines and they're good! Well maintained, clean and working, with huge varieties of television channels to watch and tune into. The theme here is no judgement. Staff is friendly and helpful. They have lots of classes to attend to learn how things work. I like the 30 minute circuit area which is a thorough workout. This has an upstairs area with a nice aerial view of the gym and feels more secluded and cozy for me. I feel very welcome in this gym. Everything seems clean and you are encouraged to wipe down machines, there is no nauseating loud music and people seem to be here to just workout and do a lot of cardio and circuit weights etc. so I think I'll be home here for a while.

New update: place still sucks.  Only real good thing is the price.

Coworkers do almost nothing but scan your card when you come in, but they don't even do that sometimes.

A decent number of people still don't wipe down the machines.

In the 30-min circuit area, people just sit and use the machines instead of doing the circuit.  I had some lady get annoyed with me when I was doing the circuit and she had to sit on her machine instead of allowing me one set.

Doesn't look easy to grab a bench so that's one reason I stick with the machines.

Parking lot remains unchanged.  People speed through the drive aisles and there is usually spit on the ground.  What is it with this place?  You have to hock loogies on the ground when you get in or out of your car?!

I almost skip my workout so I don't have to come here.  I just got an offer from another gym...hmm.
Wasn't much help for kids who never did gymnastics before when I asked for a beginners class I was told that my daughter would still b in class with girl who have been in gymnastics for years

Whether experienced or beginner climber, there's some good and some bad. We have both people, so let's get into it...

The beginner says the class was very well instructed, felt after it ended that they would be able to climb and belay with confidence. Also, had a groupon for the class plus 2 week trial and rentals for that day for $22, so no complaints there. But the class was delayed because some people showed up much later than the start time, and that's just annoying. They give classes every hour, so I'd rather you piss off the people who aren't punctual than punish the people who are. The other issue is after the class ended, I can count on one hand how many climbs were a low enough grade to complete, so it's somewhat discouraging.

The experienced one says that this place is only for people who want to boulder. If that's your thing, you'll love it, they have tons of routes at varying difficulty. But if not, don't bother. I've climbed in other east coast gyms and in California, but this gyms rankings are all over the place. There is no more technique needed on a 5-11 compared to a 5-9, just more strength. I guess why use balance and heel hooks when you can do pull-ups all day long...

Takeaway - Go here to boulder, but go elsewhere to belay climb.

I was in Philly for Thanksgiving and needed to hit a workout on Friday AM - Found Body Cycle and the first class was free. I wasn't wild about them not giving out shoes but I guess that's the spolied New Yorker in me. This kinda then set me up to think the class was gonna be lame. 

I was wrong - completely wrong. 

Jess taught class - she was on point as was her music. It's an interesting set up and the studio is also not completely dark (again another spolied NY thing, I guess?!). Jess' energy was great and kept you engaged the entire class - esp when you need that push. The music is LOUD and runs through you. It's amazing. 

This was my first time using a Keiser bike but I liked that it still had the little screen giving you the RMP's/Distance and Gear. 

Overall a great class and I shouldn't have judged a book by it's cover!

This class kicked my butt.   

The first 15 minutes were straight conditioning. Keep your body moving, try not to throw up, and you'll get through it. Also, try not to murder the instructors for inflicting such pain, I had those thoughts too.. it's fine.  After that, everything gets better.  I've been to a few different styles of kickboxing classes.  Here, you all have your own bags.  The instructor teaches a new combo and you get to practice for a short duration (3 minutes?) while the instructors help correct your form as you go.  At the end was partner drills, which they said are different every time.  
It was an amazing workout! 

The gym itself is pristine and super clean! I loved the instructors (very encouraging and outrageous amounts of high energy) and can tell the members are all like family. People that come regularly reported how important the closeness of members and accountability has been in their success of working towards their fitness goals. 

Cons: Cost. It's prettttty pricey. 
I felt like the focus was more so on intensity and endurance and less so on skill/form.

Suitable for my needs. Have arthritis through my body, just need to keep moving & try to build a little strength in the joints, nothing fancy. Good to see others here doing the same. 

Though, I too find it odd that it is supposed to be a judgement free zone & they have a lunk alarm and can kick people out for their attire.

I'm a former New Orleanian who visits often from Philly. My Philly gym is a member of IHRSA, a national organization of gyms. Supposedly when you visit other cities, if you go to another IHRSA gym, you get a discount. I looked up NOAC and they are listed as a member of IHSRA on their website. I checked them out, as I'm always in favor of frequenting unusual and historic places rather than chains, like Planet Fitness or whatever.  The membership person, a very polite and professional person, took all my info and made a copy of my license. She checked out my IHSRA "passport" which verified my membership. She said the charge is $20. That seemed high to me, so I asked if this included the IHSRA discount. She looked puzzled and said she'd have to ask someone. She disappeared for about 5 minutes and came back and apologetically told me that while they are a IHSRA facility, they don't offer a discount.

I explained that there are at least 3 other gyms in the area that are members and who offer 50% discount. From my perspective, there is no advantage to attending NOAC with my IHSRA membership. She wouldn't budge. Since my husband had dropped me off there, I decided to bite the bullet and stay. 

It would seem to me that she could have given me a pass.  Many gyms offer a free one day trial. The gym was NOT busy at all. She gave me one flimsy towel.

I had a good workout. The place is cool. I appreciate the old feel of it, with framed posters of old members and the cool tile floors and old pool. It has a lot of history to it.

The ladies changing area is nothing great. Pretty tired looking. The shower head was FREAKING awesome, but there were no grab bars or benches to sit on in the shower. This is a lawsuit waiting to happen.  Also, signage is very poor. The place is big and you kind of wander around looking for stuff.

And it ain't cheap.  Annual membership for a single person is $250 initiation fee and $88 monthly.

A much better gym is the Jewish Community Center on St. Charles Ave.  This place is a SPA in comparison. You want to spend hours in the ladies lounge. 

If NOAC wants to be competitive, they should not be so stingy. It's not that great a place where they can afford to do that.

I really like the layout of this gym.  It is big and open with plenty of machines.  Even during the peak hours, it doesn't seem overly crowded because of the large space and the many separate work out areas.  There are your standard cardio, free weight, and weight machine areas, but along with that comes raquet ball courts, a full track area, basket ball courts, an indoor golf range (cool!) and a boot camp area.  Something I love about this gym is that you can take you phone around to various spots, scan a bar code, and watch an instructional video on how to use some of the work-out props.  They also have a full class schedule with morning, afternoon and evening sessions Monday-Saturday.  Overall, this place is very impressive and membership is fairly reasonable with a $49 per month fee and $29 for add-ons in the family.

I adore this gym. 

-It's super fancy with a bunch of health and fitness geeks that come with it! 
-They have fun and hardcore group exercise classes, as well as individual trainers for those shy people. 
-They have wonderful machines and enough for everyone.
-They have a driving range for you to just hit some balls.
-They have 2 indoor basketball courts, people come with a group and play games
-They have a daycare for your offspring
-They give you little towels for you to wipe your sexy sweat off
-They play good music to get you going

So happy a spinning studio opened near graduate hospital! They have three different spinning style classes. There is a fight class that is competitive, a ride class which is a traditional spin class and a rhythm class which has choreography. I've tried all three and think they're all great! Studio is brand new and very clean. They provide shoes for free with every class. The bikes have monitors on them and there also are tvs. There are only two showers so sometimes the lines can be long in the morning. Otherwise its great! I highly recommend checking it out!

I absolutely love Row Zone. Every class provide a great full body work out out.  One of the best things about the classes are that they are not just cardio but the machine itself provides resistance and the added intervals of weight training really add a toning element.  Its different from anything else and you really do see a difference in your body and your abilities! 

They offer a variety of classes including a rowcore, bootcamp (cross fit style work out incorporating the erg) and row and flow (rowing and yoga).  There are many different packages you can get, and they all let you experience the different classes. 

The instructors are all friendly, and knowledgeable and take time to teach you how to use the machine.  The classes are all high energy, every class is different from the last and provide amazing work outs.   

The best part about Row Zone is how much of a community it is, it is like being part of a team.  Everyone who comes is there to work out and push themselves, and a high level of comradery  develops, everyone pushes each other too.  Its makes the classes fun, and fly by.  As an example they recently hosted a "Manayunk Slide" with 2,000 meter races on the ergs.  People came to race and stayed to cheer each other on.  The energy there was infections and made me really excited to be a part of it and to push myself further!

This place is a scam! They advertise and make you think that's going to be free but once you go into one of their meetings before you can become a member they want you fill out a paper. They charge you $497 and if we can make that payment they'll take installments from you. The only way to get your money back is to follow all their rules. If you don't lose then you don't get your money back... they make you advertise for them, they also make you change your profile picture to their 6 weeks challenge picture.... and also they make you leave good reviews and rate them a 4 or 5 star them... all this so you can get your money back... this place is a waste of time

Having visited the Ardmore and Radnor locations in Phila and the WSC in Columbia Heights DC, I can tell you that paying the monthly fee for the location in Fairmount is a major gyp. 

Not only does the Fairmount location lack a basketball court, swimming pool, juicing center and ample parking, it also only provides a half way decent service in the areas it should be strong in.  There are only about 15 treadmills available and there is always 1 or 2 out of service.  There is never soap in a couple of the women's soap dispensers. One of the two paper towel dispensers almost never works.  The showers overflow on a regular basis.  And the parking situation is dismal.  There are only 15 spots to park in or else you can pay $5 for a spot at whole foods per visit.  This is all pretty bad when you're paying for what should be a premium service.  The same $59 per month at another PSC location will provide all the above listed amenities at a top notch facility.  

So why come here?  If you live in the area then you're paying for the location... 

I will say the classes are really great.  They offer Pilates, cardio, spin, inter-mural type classes and the instructors are very good and encouraging and I can definitely feel a difference from that.  

But as far the facility is concerned, management is only concerned with signing up new contracts so don't expect any of these complaints to turn into realized changes.
Phenomenal facility, friendly staff and members, great equipment and just a great overall atmosphere to workout in and reach your goals.

I've visited this location a number of times over the one closest to me because of the variety and amount of fitness classes offered! This location has a pool, newer equipment, racquetball, basketball, & cycle areas. The staff is courteous & professional. I always get a good workout here.

Standard globo gym. The staff at the front desk couldn't be bothered to smile or actually be nice to you. After stopping in to look at the gym while traveling in the area, I was told that there would be a charge for working out each day I was in town. I have no problem paying a fee, as I'm not a member. However, the manner in which I was told this by the front desk was curt and gave off the appearance of "why are you wasting my time by asking me this?" - I was then told that I could walk around and see the gym to decide if I wanted to workout, which was nice. After leaving the gym I found a workout pass online, at the company website, that indicated a workout was free. I printed it out and brought it back later and was able to work out. However, when I walked back into the gym the same person I spoke with before refused to help me check in.

I used to be a member at the Twelve Oaks location even though I live in Seminole Heights, so I was happy when the Florida Ave. location opened. 

So far, I am very happy with the gym. There are more machines to choose from than the Twelve Oaks location, which is great for variety. There is a room with TRX equipment if that is something you're into. There is a large selection for cardio, free weights as well as other machines. I've attended in the mornings, evenings, on weekdays and weekends and it's never too busy to work out. I've never had to wait more than 5 minutes for a piece of equipment. 

The gym staff is nice and the managers are helpful. One particular employee didn't seem to know the gym as well as he should but it doesn't influence my opinion of this gym or the gym location. 

There are three changing stalls and 4 showers, including a handicap assessable shower and changing stall. There are also plenty of lockers with and without combinations built in. Drinks are also available for purchase if you forget yours. 

I was even able to get my mom to buy into the gym, and she hates going to the gym. She was looking for something cheaper than a yoga membership that still provides variety for working out. This gym atmosphere is not like usual gyms. There are all walks of life that attend and it's easy to feel comfortable when working out alone.
Brand new and super clean YMCA. Big basketball court always teeming with kids, impeccable cardio and weight area. Nice, friendly staff. Great addition to the neighborhood. (Nice parking lot, too.)

One of the worst experiences I have had with a gym. I was told when I first signed up that I would have guest passes so that I would be able to bring my boyfriend. When I did bring him in, he was turned away. They said my membership did not include that and would not even offer a one day guest pass for him. When I first joined, I also did the one complementary hour with a personal trainer. Which I waited for 45 minutes for the trainer to come available, even though I scheduled an appointment a week in advance. While he was trying incredibly too hard to sell me, he told me there was no way I was going to be able to loose weight unless I worked with them. After I declined, every time he would see me in the gym he would continue to try to sell me on working with a trainer and made me pretty uncomfortable. After I had enough with the gym I called their corporate to find out how the cancellation works. Which I was told I my membership would be cancelled that day and I would get a credit for what I paid in advance. When I went in to cancel the girl at the desk pretty much called me a liar and said I was not going to get a credit and that's how it was going to be. After, I called corporate and was made to feel like I was a liar again and was told  that they were not going to do anything. 

I will tell every person I come in contact with not to join that gym. Biggest mistake I made.

So glad I'm a member of this gym! The facility is clean and there are plenty of different machines to use. They have several group classes you can attend. The Zumba ones are always packed and a good time. They have member rates for various employers, so don't hesitate to ask the friendly staff at the desk if you get employee rates . You might be surprised with how reasonable the prices can be. :)

I usually attend the Holiday, Fl Location, but since my Beau lives more closely there, we meet here to work out after work. 

This gym is well lit, with a large work out area filled with an assortment of machines.  There are areas for Abs, free weights and the 30 minute circuit as well as the Ropes area. 

The Lifestyle machines for weights are well kept and everyone wipes them down between their usage. 

Depending on your level of membership, you can tan or even get an aquassage (a massage table that uses controlled jets of massage to relax you) or use a massage chair. 

It's a really nice facility.

The Mecca Gym is a gem of a training facility located in a strip mall area right off the freeway in Meridian, ID.  It is tucked back in such a way as to allow for back door access to the back lot for Prowler runs, farmer's walks and tire flipping.  

Owned by local natural bodybuilders and powerlifters, Eric and Kacee Cafferty, the locals all have a sense of ownership and familial bonding after only one visit to this gym.  Go in without your headphones on and you'll see what we mean.  Everyone is friendly, willing to help, coach, co-train and chat about pretty much anything.  We saw a 130# gossipy female (very entertaining) trying to pr her squat with a 210# beefcake mainstay of the club.  

All of the equipment is top-of-the-line and the Cafferty's own several unique pieces we have not seen anywhere in the Treasure Valley.  These include a Nautilus pec-deck straight from Venice Beach, a Roger's squat (if you haven't worked your ass-quads-core in this remarkable piece of equipment, a visit to The Mecca Gym is worth it just for that.) and a seal row bench.  The powerlifting staples are of the best quality we've seen in the entire state and if you are trying to just work on your Big 3, this is your gym.

Cardio equipment consists of a row of treadmills and a step mill.  They also own a Jacob's Ladder, which is great.  The step mill has no platform for a phone or iPad to watch a movie so that's disappointing.

The staff is all sincerely friendly with welcome greetings, big furry smiles and surprisingly, the females don't annoy us with their friendly chatter.  The "Mecca Family" (meaning the members) are always available to help spot you, inform you or give you a tip on how to hit that little-know muscle group or to share a new delicious recipe.

The reason we gave The Mecca gym only 4 of 5 stars is that it also offers tanning and childcare-neither of which are note-worthy or worth it.  The child care room is always unmanned and you have to ask a staff member to hang out with your kids.  This would be fine for older children, but if you have a little one, training over an hour gets you feeling guilty as there are RARELY any kids to play with here.  They do have a tv and the kids can watch movies or play with the plethora of trucks, baby toys or a toy kitchen.  Also, there is really no set limit on the childcare hours like at other facilities so you could come with the kids at 3 am and train until noon if you so chose.  Also, you could let your kids hang out with you on the floor as long as they are well-behaved.  This is something you really don't see.  The tanning bed was used by us twice in a row and not a drop of color after 15 minutes which tells us that the bulbs must need changing.

All-in-all, this is decidedly FABULOUS gym and we could train here for hours!

Best rock gym in the philadelphia area, hands down.  Nice staff, and decent amount of routes. Would really like it if they expanded and got more space, can get a little crowded, but besides that, my first pick for climbing indoors in Philly...

I got my hair cut here and it was awful. She failed to trim the back. The top was poorly done and there were forgotten strands sticking out everywhere. There still are. She had no idea what she was doing. I have never gotten a cut this bad. I even came back the next day for her to fix it and she only made it worse. I'm going to Groom on Tuesday to see if they can mitigate the damage. Im at a loss for how this kind of place can have such terrible talent.

If I paid $25, I would be happy too but I'm suspecting other reviewers pay more like I do ($40 a month they charge some members) and  we expect more. The TVs on the equipment are dying, certain classes are always full, not enough parking, and half the bikes in the spin class are broken. 

 
It's a good gym but it has its flaws like any other. If you can get a membership for $25/mo, go for it. But for around $40, keep in mind the issues I brought up, then it stops being a good deal for what you get.

A significant sized YMCA with many group exercise options. Upper track is good for walk/run off treadmill. If you use everything and need daycare, highly recommend. If you just want weights/machines then it may be better to just find a gym at a lower price.

The YMCA is like my second home.   It feels like I spend more time here than anywhere.  Everyone is super friendly, almost obnoxiously so (but that's better than the alternative).  I really enjoy taking group fitness classes, and I like that I don't have to pay extra to attend them.  I use the childcare at least twice a week, and the workers know my daughter by name.  I have no worries about leaving her in their care.  Often it gets busy in January so you might struggle to get your favorite machine (but don't all gyms?).  If you want to avoid the crowd, go when the child care isn't open, and you'll be sure to have unlimited choices and fewer folks around you.

This gym is fine for bouldering but their policy for belaying is inexplicably restrictive. I have climbed frequently at about 4 other climbing gyms in major cities (including San Francisco and Philadelphia) and everywhere I've ever been, a climbing gym will allow paying guests to become trained in belaying, pass a test to prove they can operate the equipment safely, and become certified to belay their friends. At SB Rock Gym, they refused to allow my guests to become trained in belaying. I still don't understand why. Their staff members insisted that there is no place in the country that will allow you to become certified in belaying and immediately climb thereafter, but that statement is belied by my own experience at Mission Cliffs (SF), Planet Granite (SF) and Go Vertical (Philly) and a few other places. 

They also inexplicably refused to allow me to bring in my own Vibram 5-finger shoes (which I have used for climbing for the last 5 years at least, without any problem), and made me rent their shoes for $6. It was a real pain and they gave no good reason why I couldn't climb in my own shoes that I prefer for climbing. 

Their bouldering wall is fine but if you're looking to come here with friends to climb and belay, and you're not already certified here, then I don't recommend this place.

You'd never expect a gym like this at a hotel!  Carpet everywhere, quality weights, strength, and cardio equipment. The tvs on the cardio equipment are awkward - takes forever to find your channel. I've stayed in Reno 1-2 times per month for the past 14 years, and I stay at The Peppermill because of the upgraded rooms, covered parking, and the gym.

This was the first city I've tried Barry's bootcamp in (so no other cities to compare it to). I have attended several HIIT gyms previously, all were similar. You split your hour between the treadmill and the floor (weights, bands).

I really enjoyed the trainers (all very nice), and the workout routines on the floor. Each day focuses on a different area- upper body, lower body, total body, etc. You can put in as little or as much effort as you want- you WILL be sore the following day! There is ONE spot for "double floor" (DF) routine, if you need a break from the treadmill. 

This leads me to the only true negative I have- it is close to impossible to get the DF spot. You are able to book classes up to a week in advance, but people seem to just WAIT for the DF spot to open and reserve it immediately. Would definitely suggest adding more DF spots. 

Only other negative is that if you cancel within 24 hours of class, you are charged $10. I understand how other gyms do it- they charge you if you cancel within ONE hour of your reserved class, but 24 hours seems a bit extreme (especially since all of us have unforeseen circumstances, particularly with work). 

Other than that, I really enjoyed the time I spent going to the gym. It was easy to get to (and parking in the garage next door is free), clean, and had plenty of equipment. I would definitely return if more DF spots opened up!!
Very good equipment and never crowded. The view of the Catalinas is breathtaking. I love the place.

This club is the original LA Fitness in the Tucson area, opening in 2004. It was recently rebranded by LA Fitness as Esporta. ( who knows why but it doesn't really matter) on 10/25/2021 the club was gone over, again, with more new equipment and an entire area designated for "functional" fitness. While I always thought of the term Functional Fitness as being just another gimmick to sell fitness videos, the equipment that was brought in is very useful in completing a whole body workout. The TRX stations and sled are a much needed addition to any gym. Also two power racks with deadlift stations were included in this most recent remodel with rubberized weights much needed when deadlifting. 

AND they kept the good old equipment, like the hammer chest and back machines.  Well done. Plenty of dumbell weights are still available. I understand the two old squat racks will be returned to service soon as well. 

If you are looking for a decent workout, and not training for a specialized sport ( CrossFit, powerlifting, Olympic lifting) I recommend this gym.
Avoid this place unless you just want to use the pool. We got terrible massages. Not worth the $.

I signed up for their 30 days for $30 option at the end of July. The day I went in to activate it, they offered me August for free if I signed up that day plus a refund of my $30. Well. After 2 weeks and three conversations, that switched to "it will be applied as a $30 credit to your September membership fee." Naturally, it wasn't applied.

Almost six weeks after being promised my refunded money and seven attempts to get this resolved, I am still without my money.

Not to mention, the pool was closed for over a month, the equipment isn't usually clean, and the staff is clearly really unhelpful.

How is it even legal to run businesses like this?

Update: After 15 attempts to contact they finally resolved this issue. The time and effort it took for me to get this resolved though does not change my rating. 

And a new update (November 2014): I realized I wasn't charged my monthly rate for November. I called FIVE times over the period of a week before someone returned my call. I just saw the transaction hit my account and they overcharged me $15. And guess what. Three calls later they have yet to return my call. If I do not receive a refund for my overcharging ASAP, I'm reporting them to the better business bureau. Absolutely avoid this place at all cost.

Yet another update (December 2014): I have yet to receive my refund. They refuse to call me back, and I had to report them to the better business bureau. Jamie at this location is a joke. It is alarming the amount of effort I am putting in to even speak with her regarding this matter. She has YET to call me back, meaning I have to call almost daily in the hopes of speaking with her.

Joined VASA Tucson in mid Feb. 2020. Went 1 month and was charged $26. Was charged $20 for a 2nd month the day before they closed on March 17 for the following month. Then charged yearly fee of $50 in mid April when they were closed. Received notice day before they reopened at the end of August and was told I would be charged another $20 for use of the gym until mid October when I told them I will not be returning due to covid-19 concerns. At least they responded to emails this time, which they did not do when they closed in March. Numbers are rounded up on charges from 19.99 to 20 and 49.99 to 50. Do not think charges are fair and believe that I was overcharged almost $90.

Forget the intimidation of being new at a gym. Everyone here is super welcoming. Cycle sculpt and cycle strength are great classes, and you will leave class feeling the burn. Shanna at the front desk is amazing and she takes time to remember your name so you always feel welcomed.

They charged me membership fees during Covid even though they were closed.  I gave them written notice to cancel my membership, and they said I needed to come in for that, BUT THEY WERE CLOSED DUE TO COVID!!!  I contested the charges and my bank got my money back. 
Then they contacted me in July and stated that I still needed to come in and cancel!!  Unknowingly, they were still billing me, even though I was not paying them.  Now it's September and I get a notice from their billing department that I own them $225!!  The manager named Mary Beth would not do anything about the charges, she said she does not make up the rules.  How can you stay in business when you treat people this way?

I decided to use this gym while I was in NJ for a few weeks. 

First impression: 
The facility's aesthetics was a definite pleaser. The newness of this facility makes it that much more of an encouragement to use the gym. However it is no Equinox!!

Pros: 
First, the treadmill seemed above par in technology - your stats are all in a digital LCD screen. In addition, the treadmill has a TV (which is pretty standard in most gyms now), but doesn't have a built in fan (a bummer if you are use to that amenity). There are plenty of cardio equipments (i.e. treadmills, ellipticals, cycling, stepper). I've never had an issue finding a treadmill. Second, there is a track that goes around the gym. This is great for people who actually want to run or walk outside of the treadmill. Third, I appreciate that they utilize disinfectant wipes for cleaning equipment. My gym in Chicago uses a spray with paper towels throughout the facility. I suppose it's less wasteful. Fourth, the locker room is really fancy. It looks like teak wood and the lockers are all digitally locked (no need to bring your own master lock!). They have nice towels, a separate restrooms and a shower room. Fifth, there is an amazing pool room. I believe one is for kids, one is for recreational use, and another is for distance swimming. Lastly, for the most part the trainers have been nice.  

Cons: 
The downsides to the gym became apparent to me after first use. First, I use the TRX suspensions in my gym in Chicago which is open to EVERYONE. Apparently in Virtua's Wellness Center, only clients are allowed to use this secretive room. Fortunately, I've been able to use the TRX when I asked some trainers, while others including some blonde female was really rude about how it was only for clients. I don't really appreciate this exclusive attitude towards certain equipment. That dismissive, non-inclusive attitude is a reason why some people avoid the gym. 

I wish there was more room and mirrors. Since the TRX room is only for clients, I was unsure If I was even allowed to use the studio to do Pilates or use jump ropes. They have a little room in the carpeted area between the studio and the cardio equipments. It's really weird to do some workouts without a mirror. I kind of wish they had mirrors in that wall so I can see if I am doing my movements right. I am use to my gym in Chicago with mirrors everywhere, even in the pillars. 

I would recommend the gym to put a monthly calendar of classes that are used in those specific studio spaces. It would make it easier for those of us who just want to use the space for simple exercises and stretches and know when we have to leave before a class starts. 

That prone curl/hamstring machine... I have only ever seen one person use it. I have used a completely different one in my gym in Chicago. This machine has you lay on your stomach long. If you are short like me, there is no way you can hold on to those handles and have your legs curl with your legs spread out the way the machine has it laid out. I've had to use the cable cross to work on my hamstrings instead :( Also, no stair master! What is this...

On a few occasions, I've had people come up to me whenever I was doing Pilates. I looked at the biographies of the trainers at this facility and it seemed generic (no offense). No one had expertise in Pilates or yoga. I am not a fitness guru, but I have my share of experience. I think this facility would be surprised to see the interest in different programs like Pilates, yoga, barre, and TRX. I don't know if it's just a south jersey thing, or they are just really bad at advertising.

Although I have some detailed cons, I cannot help but like this facility. It really is a clean facility. Everyone seems to know each other and are generally polite. Considering this is a new facility, it still has room for improvement to give it that competitive advantage to Retro Fitness or LA Fitness.

Mr Johns Steak House, is without a doubt the finest steak house I have been to in the 504.
From the minute you sit down, 'till you walk out the door, you are treated so well.
My steak, a Rare Pittsburg style Rib-Eye was impeccable, cooked to perfection.
My side of sautéed mushrooms and potatoes au gratin, could not have been better.
The price is similar to other steak houses of this level, but so worth the $43.00 for my Rib-Eye.
Looking for a  special place, for a special date, or just have a craving for a gorgeous cut of read meat cooked to perfection.
Mr John's is the place for you my friend..
And I am..
Da Big Easy Daddy..

I would give them 0 stars if I could I went in yesterday to take a look at this gym as they kept sending me texts to join. I spoke with a very arrogant personal trainer by the name of Paul he looked annoyed as I was asking questions.  I told him I spoke to someone a few months ago about joining the gym . At that time they told me it would be 60.00 a month . Paul however, told me it was basied on a point system and any questions to ask mangement . Wow no happiness in his voice just pure rudeness. He then explained how the do the analysis testing and pulled up his own profile . I explained to Paul that I have recently had to go in a have several biopsies done for Cervical Cancer and if I join would they customize a fitness plan for me ? He then quoted Cancer is caused by one eating too much sugar that stays in the stomach area causing inflammation to the designed area . I was shocked actually asshole Paul Cancer is caused by me having family members who have all died from it and it was passed down to me . Educate yourself please before you speak . Needless to say after that conversation I went home and joined Chooze on Grant and Swan for they certainly did not judge me because I am a survivor of Cervical Cancer.
Instructors encourage bad form... "class" is super easy.  They tell you to do a handful of reps for three or four different exercises snd then tell you to go home.  Not worth what they charge.

16.5 in the books thanks to TYLER and his great box. The place is great. Everyone is very welcoming and Tyler is spot on. Minimal coaching since I was there only to be judged for 16.5 but that WOD is a killer and Tyler got me through it, even though I'd met him only 20 mins prior. Great form and pacing corrections!!!  Thanks!!!

Over the years, I have had many friends invite me to join them for a cycling class, but my response was always "No, thank you. Spinning is the one exercise that I just can't do!" Most recently, my daughter started going and after renewing her 2nd package of classes with SoHo, her excitement and enjoyment of the classes piqued my interest, so she booked us bikes for a morning class with Stephen. I was both intrigued and intimidated but willing to give it a whirl.

Reservations aside, we wandered into the studio at the ungodly hour of 5:45 in the morning, ready.

We were warmly greeted at the front desk and enthusiastically checked in, given shoes and resistance bands and I followed my girl to the lockers and then into the studio. The room was dark, and the music was already pumping. Stephen recognized a "newbie" and asked if I needed help (I DID!). He adjusted my bike and helped me get clipped in.
I sat there a moment and my daughter told me to start pedaling. I told her I thought it best to conserve my energy, but she insisted that I had to warm up. After a few moments, the class began, and I was transported to a completely different world.  The 3 huge video screens kept me in a zone, music pumped through my veins, and my legs hypnotically cycled to the beat. 

I kept up as best as I could and Stephen's welcome words of "this is a judgement free zone!" kept going through my head. My self-doubts were gloriously silenced. There in the studio, it didn't matter how early in the morning it was, what the people around me were wearing or if I felt better on the saddle while everyone else was running. It was all good!

Before I knew it, the 45 minutes were over, and we had rocked through an entire session filled with speed, hills and strength. As we cooled down and stretched out, I felt like I was on top of the world -- and it still wasn't even light outside yet. 

I now understand the power behind SoHo's loyal following. Stephen, Cisco, Michelle, and the rest of the SoHo Cycling team, thank you!!! for providing an amazing ride! I think this is the beginning of a beautiful friendship.
Old school gym is awesome and the owner is a great guy. I didn't join because I live 20 miles away. Bummed

Things I love about Cityway Y: 
- Location- perfect for those downtown looking for a space for wellness
- Cleanliness- The space is new, clean, and aesthetically pleasing
- A space for all- Regardless of where you are on your wellness journey, there is something for you here!  A high intensity course? check.  At your own pace walking?  got it.  The Y offers a place where you can find something that's right for you! 
- Fun classes- I'm a sucker for classes and I love the variety of encouraging teachers!

What I'm a little sad about: 
- It feels the Y hasn't accommodated for the influx of guests and members with the new year/ opening.  Those bringing guests have to wait in line for longer than 15 minutes at a time for their guest pass on a weekday morning.  I'm hoping they add more staff to streamline the process soon!  It's a bummer that this is many people's first impression.  
- The two lane walking track is a bit smushed.. 

Overall, super pumped to pump some iron at Cityway (okay.. let's be real, I'm more of a yoga, zumba, kick-boxing girl).

Burg Fitness is a great locally owned gym where the owners and instructors treat you like family.  I enjoy the variety of classes and cycling.  This is not a pretentious gym so I feel comfortable every time I walk in the door!  The space is clean, top notch equipment and a great location downtown with parking.

Best in Tucson for the corporate gyms. We were gold/platinum members until LA opened up down the street, and we've never looked back.

Update- the focus on trainers and the enhanced membership made me a second class member; area now restricted. 

A large section of the gym designed for stretching now requires an enhanced membership to enter. Some of the mats, rowers, and such have found their way to the main floor. However, it has narrowed walkways and made cluttered areas. Saddened by new management and new focus.  Weekday cleaning guy still tops!

A hidden gem in Cherry Hill off of Route 70 & Frontage Road.  

My friend rented the private party room for her daughter's 9th birthday, which oversaw the whole awesome gym below.  (she had pizza delivered plus had 'snicky snacks' of fresh fruit, Doritos, Goldfish crackers & Hershey Kisses on hand).  

There was a ton a great equipment (foam block pit, Bounce House, trampolines, etc) for the kids to enjoy - especially the zip line and one largest trampoline, where the kids took turns being strapped in and hoisted way up high (all the way up to the specatating parents in the party room - so cool!).   

The young employees were really fun, energetic and into their jobs.  They were totally on top of giving equipment instructions, safety and keeping lines in order.  I was impressed.  

They also were mindful of the party's timeframe and well organized.  

My guys are teetering on being "too old" (12 1/2 & pushing 14!)  for this great facility but had fun anyway.

I'd highly reccommend 'Gynnastics & Cheerleading Academy' for kids from ages 5 - 11.    Great and memorable party.  (They have summer camp as well).

Pros: 
This was our first time visiting here. The staff was friendly, spacious facility with plenty of seating and plenty of parking. There is an onsite concession stand available which offers drinks and various snack items for visitors to enjoy. There are plenty of trampoline areas to enjoy ranging from basketball, dodgeball, open jump arena, jump pit and more along with laser tag which is included with your wristband purchase. 

Cons:
Couple of things regarding our first visit here would mainly be about the air quality (smell) within this facility which smelled like a sweaty locker room with absolutely no ventilation. I would certainly hate to be in there during the summer months when tempuratures are nice and warm. They do have fans but they really don't help. Needless to say, stepping outside for a breath of fresh air was a real treat. Parking can be a bit challenging during the early evening hours but there is additional parking in the street. 

Suggestions:
Consider the idea of having better airflow quality within your facility so that it doesn't smell like gym socks and especially for individuals with asthma that are sensitive to poor air quality (because of this, not sure that we will be returning) Not everyone has Facebook; consider opening a Twitter account to broadcast your specials and other announcements which help drive more revenue by extending your customer base via social media.

This Club and Company are disastrous, I recently canceled, or rather tried canceling my membership with them after 2 yrs of putting up with their crappy gym, and they helped themselves to my checking account! so beware of what you sign, because you will end up paying months after you cancel.

So besides this,how's the Gym ? well, equipment is broken more often than not,and the poor lonely guy trying to fix everything can't cope;staff is hopeless and will gladly ignore someone about to break their spine while trying to chat up the cute girl in the corner,it is also quite unhygienic, blood and luggies with your daily run ,anyone ? The clientèle is a mix of White and Latino that will a) leave the bench press loaded with 400lbs for you to unload and b) leave the seat and back of the machine sweaty and ready for you to clean, It also gets quite crowded at times.  

I remember fondly that one time that an older guy was shaving IN the pool !  while I was trying to swim, and then I got ignored by the manager when I complained, how's that for customer service ?

Sadly, as mentioned before there are not that many other options as far as gyms in Downtown Santa Barbara, and if you join a gym you will get fitter, just beware that this particular one will test you in other ways.

Ooh, and I hope you like Andre Agassi on the speaker repeating himself over and over and over, ah the horror the horror.

I will try running on the beach path from now on.

I loved this gym. I was a loyal member for 3 good years, before I moved to an area with zero Retro Fitness gyms, and had to cancel my membership. I like Retro Fitness because all of their gyms use Life Fitness equipment, which are top of the line machines and very expensive. I also like their cardio theater A LOT. Not many gyms have this feature, this, I've come to realize. For $20 a month, this is truly the best value you can get out of a gym membership. 

When I see or hear people complain about Retro, it bothers me, because honestly, what were you expecting? Maybe it doesn't have a lot of classes or the child care is not that great, but for $20/month, great machines, a cardio theater, some classes, sounds like a great deal to me. I rather go to Retro Fitness than pay an extra $15/month at LA Fitness for a swimming pool and a few more classes. 

Finally, I've never had a problem with membership fees, or cancelling it when I moved. I've read some horror stories of how some people being hit with fees when trying to cancel their membership, but this has never happened to me.

I miss Retro :'(
Don't get it twisted this place is in Trenton. Great mirror surface area by all the weights and machines. heavy duty leg press. Everyone is cool. Great place

This is not your typical gym! The coaches are educated and passionate about being healthy and strong. the classes are small enough to give you personal attention and make sure you're in proper form. I've been able to push myself, gain strength and learn to love working out in a safe supportive space. The classes always change and keep you interested, I fully recommend alaris to all of my friends and am grateful to have found it.

I use the fitness Centre from time to time because I live up Ameling my house is in the big houses before you get to Rule (parkway side of Ameling not the Pattonville side). So I live very close, sometimes I walk to the community centre for a pre workout warmup. I also like that it's next to aqua port. It would be really nice if they built the new facility as they plan to, the pictures look really cool! I'd be happy to pay a $200 a year usage fee for a $30,000,000 new facility with all the things of the old Centre only a lot bigger and nicer plus a lap pool... I can't wait, hopefully it happens before I move to Chesterfield or Seattle in a couple years.

I've been going to Orangetheory for about four years and have attended over 15 studios around the state. I just came home from North Tampa on a business trip and attended this studio's 5am class for each of the three days I was there, and I must say, this studio rocked. 

The front desk staff and sales associates were some of the most friendly I've ever met! They all treated me as if I was a new member of their studio, not just a visitor. They all seemed genuinely happy to have me there and were all very welcoming. When I said goodbye on my last morning, they said "OH NO ITS YOUR LAST DAY?!" which I thought was cute. Thanks for making me feel at home, guys!

The studio itself is one of the largest I've been to. I loved how the rowers were in the middle of the room- it makes mobility much easier. 

I took Mikaela's classes and she played incredible music, was friendly and energetic. She made waking up at 4:30am while on business actually something to look forward to.

My only gripe with this studio is their sound system sucks. It's really muffled and hard to understand what the coaches are saying. But other than that, you can NOT go wrong here. Thank you OTF New Tampa for both incredible workouts and the warm hospitality!

Walked in and manger Wayne introduced himself professionally and I was fairly specific in that I just wanted a day visitor pass and immediately he asks for my license for some presentation tour.
